channel.title: [TUT]python in depth
channel.description:
Okai for all of oyu who ahave a hard time understanding java heres a language that has all of the same funcionality and none of the hassle, Python! here are a few tutorials for you to get started none of hem are scripting related their just good python tutorials to get you started. first off if u dont already have it grab a copy of activestate python just google it or look in my other python tut for a link.
now for the tuts: [url=http://honors.montana.edu/~jjc/easytut/easytut/]http://honors.montana.edu/~jjc/easytut/easytut/[/url] this is a great tutorial if you just want a quick crash course to get the feel of things [url=http://docs.python.org/tut/tut.html]http://docs.python.org/tut/tut.html[/url] this tut here is more for people who want to know alot about python and have some time on their hand although it is a little less understandable i highly recommend it over the other one
The information inside those tutorials will aid you in the creation of your scripts BUT you will need MODULES to cover the things that you cannot do with python as is (packet monitoring and such)
here is a link to a list of modules it has almost ALL of the modules out their [url=http://docs.python.org/modindex.html]http://docs.python.org/modindex.html[/url] so enjoy and i hope that some of us make the switch to python because script production could probably double :) oh and can you guys please tell me if you found this useful or not
edit: i dont now how many of you are on linux probably none but anyways heres a link to a linux python module for monitoring packets [url=http://www.secdev.org/projects/scapy]http://www.secdev.org/projects/scapy[/url]
Edit: yay i found you guys a windows version of the packet capturer although you guys will have to figure it out on your own but it shouldnt be to hard[url=http://monkey.org/~dugsong/pypcap/]http://monkey.org/~dugsong/pypcap/[/url]
Edit: j python to java converter can be found here [url=http://www.jython.org]www.jython.org[/url] but your on your own when using it seeing as i havent figured it out all the way myself lol

item.title: [TUT]python in depth
item.dc:creator: @Pyro Pyro
item.description:
@Pyro wrote:

I started learnign python a long itme ago. But i always start a language then leave it before it gets interesting. Like i finsih of all the maths functions and the loops and all the basics but then leave and onto next language.

Might go back though

Read full topic

item.title: [TUT]python in depth
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

tyvm, i cant do java yet but i wana help out the community. I hope others will catch on also...

o and btw, post how python scripts can be converted into java and mabey a link to the converter? thanks for bringing this to the community

I found this, i'm really too lazy to read it right now. but its all about python code in java
http://www.jython.org/docs/whatis.html

Read full topic

item.title: [TUT]python in depth
item.dc:creator: @sh4d0ws sh4d0ws
item.description:
@sh4d0ws wrote:

Okai for all of oyu who ahave a hard time understanding java heres a language that has all of the same funcionality and none of the hassle, Python!
here are a few tutorials for you to get started none of hem are scripting related their just good python tutorials to get you started.
first off if u dont already have it grab a copy of activestate python
just google it or look in my other python tut for a link.

now for the tuts: http://honors.montana.edu/~jjc/easytut/easytut/ this is a great tutorial if you just want a quick crash course to get the feel of things
http://docs.python.org/tut/tut.html this tut here is more for people who want to know alot about python and have some time on their hand although it is a little less understandable
i highly recommend it over the other one

The information inside those tutorials will aid you in the creation of your scripts BUT you will need MODULES to cover the things that you cannot do with python as is (packet monitoring and such)

here is a link to a list of modules it has almost ALL of the modules out their http://docs.python.org/modindex.html
so enjoy and i hope that some of us make the switch to python because script production could probably double oh and can you guys please tell me if you found this useful or not

edit: i dont now how many of you are on linux probably none but anyways heres a link to a linux python module for monitoring packets
http://www.secdev.org/projects/scapy

Edit: yay i found you guys a windows version of the packet capturer although you guys will have to figure it out on your own but it shouldnt be to hardhttp://monkey.org/~dugsong/pypcap/

Edit: j python to java converter can be found here www.jython.org but your on your own when using it seeing as i havent figured it out all the way myself lol

Read full topic
